The application of heteropoly acid catalyst in methacrolein (MAL) oxidation reaction is limited for its poor thermal stability and few active centers. Here, the supported catalyst of P-Mo-V heteropoly acid (CsNH4KPMoV) active components supported on kaolin were prepared, and were characterized by FT-IR, TG/DTA, XRD, N2-adsorption and desorption, NH3-TPD, TPO-MS and XPS. The results show that kaolin was weak acidity and the negative charge on the surface of kaolin promoted the reduction of V5+ species to V4+(VO2+) active species. There was a strong electron interaction between kaolin and HPVA, and chemical adsorption occurred by DFT calculations. Under optimal conditions, higher MAL conversion (81.8%) and Methacrylic acid (MAA) selectivity (88.2%) were obtained by 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin catalyst. The Keggin structure was maintained and the acid strength and acidity did not decrease after the catalyst was used continuously for 100 h. There was no carbon deposition in the reaction process. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Keggin heteropoly acid Kaolin Supported catalyst Methacrolein Methacrylic acid Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Methacrylic acid (MAA) is an important chemical intermediate, which can be used to synthesize methyl methacrylate (MMA) [1–4] and further synthesize poly-methyl-methacrylate (PMMA), synthetic rubber, functional plastics [5–9], etc. The traditional synthesis method of synthesizing MAA is acetone-cyanohydrin (ACH) method. However, the process uses toxic hydrocyanic acid and corrosive H2SO4, which does not meet the requirements of green chemistry [10,11]. The oxidation of methacrolein (MAL) to MAA by Keggin-type heteropoly acid (HPAs) catalysts has the advantages of high atomic utilization and low pollution [7,12,13], and the gas-phase oxidation reaction equation is shown in Scheme 1 [5]. HPAs, as a kind of important acidic and redox catalysts especially those with Keggin structure, have attracted more and more research interest in recent years [10,14–19]. HPAs have been widely used as oxidation catalysts in various homogeneous and heterogeneous reactions, in which Keggin-type HPAs catalysts containing P, Mo and V are often used for the oxidation of MAL [10,20,21]. At present, many methods have been taken to improve the catalytic performance of Keggin-type HPAs. The main methods include replacing some Mo atoms with V atoms, or replacing some protons with alkali metal ions and transition metal ions [11,20,22–27], etc. In our previous work, the effect of K+ counterions on the catalytic performance of P-Mo-V HPAs was studied [3]. However, it is well known that the specific surface area of HPAs is low, generally 3–5 m2·g−1, and the thermal stability of HPAs is poor [28–32]. In addition, HPAs also has the problems of few active centers and easy decomposition of active components [33,34]. In recent years, researchers usually dispersed HPAs on SiO2, Al2O3, SBA-15, TiO2, MCM-41, HMS and other supports with high surface areas to prepare highly active catalysts and solve these problems [35–39]. These supported HPAs catalysts have been widely used in dehydration reaction of ethanol and methanol to ether [40], oxidation of glycerol to formic acid [41], esterification of glycerol with acetic acid [42], Baeyer-Villiger oxidation of cyclic ketones [14], and the results indicate that the performance are related to the type of carriers. It is reported that the supported catalyst has been used in the oxidative synthesis of MAA. Mitsuru Kanno et al. supported H4PMo11VO40 (HPVA) on SiO2 for MAL oxidation to MAA, the activity of catalysts was improved [28]. N. Ballarini et al. [43] supported Keggin-type P/Mo polyoxometalates (POMs) on silica gel and the specific surface area of the catalyst increased. HPAs have high dispersibility when supported on 1D mesoporous channels of SBA-15 and MCM-41 [12]. However, the supported catalyst generally exhibits poor thermal stability and low conversion in the reaction process. The main reason is that the reaction between the carrier and HPAs leads to the decomposition of Keggin unit or neutralizing the partial acidity of HPAs [28,29]. Moreover, amphoteric and basic carriers like Al2O3 and MgO will reduce the acidity of HPAs and decompose the structure of HPAs [40,44]. In view of the above problems, the researchers adopt the method of modification to adjust the acidity and basicity of the carrier. For example, SiO2 was modified with ammonia and SBA-15 was modified with melamine [5,37]. The acidity and alkalinity of the support has a great influence on the performance of the catalyst. When the carrier exhibits obvious alkalinity, the HPAs will interact with the carrier, resulting in the decomposition of the active components and reducing the catalytic activity [38,45]. A certain acidity is necessary to activate MAL for the nucleophilic attack oxygen atom, however, too strong acidity enhance the adsorption of MAL and affect the reoxidation rate [46] and decrease MAA selectivity [37]. Therefore, the selection of weakly acidic or neutral carriers with high temperature resistance is of great significance for the preparation of supported HPAs catalysts. As a kind of aluminum-rich silicate, kaolin is natural mineral with 2D layered morphology of mild acidic minerals [47–50] and a heterogeneous surface charge [51,52]. The high specific surface area, good adsorption performance and a large number of hydroxyl groups on the surface make kaolin widely used in many fields, such as cosmetics, ceramics, paints, etc [51,53,54]. Based on the above advantages of kaolin, if kaolin is used as a carrier to load HPAs, the decomposition of active components (HPAs) can be avoided and the efficiency of oxidation synthesis of MAA by MAL can be improved. In this work, the kaolin-supported Cs+-NH4 +-K+ doping P-Mo-V Keggin-type HPAs catalysts (CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin) were prepared. The morphology and property of catalysts before and after loading were characterized by FT-IR, XRD, TG/DTA, XPS, NH3-TPD and N2 adsorption-desorption. The structural stability of CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin and the electronic interaction between kaolin support and CsNH4KPMoV active components were revealed by density functional theory (DFT) calculation. The catalytic oxidation of MAL to MAA was carried out in a fixed-bed reactor. The effects of CsNH4KPMoV loading and reaction temperature on the performance of the catalyst were investigated. In addition, the long-term stability test of the catalyst was performed by continuous reaction for 100 h. And the crystal phase, acidity and carbon deposition of the used catalysts were analyzed by XRD, NH3-TPD, TPO-MS. It is hoped that this work could provide a catalyst with high stability and high catalytic performance for the synthesis of MAA. 2 Experimemtal section 2.1 Materials Molybdenum trioxide (≥99.9%), vanadium oxide (≥98%), phosphoric acid (≥85%) and cesium hydroxide (≥99%) were purchased from Aladdin Chemistry Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Potassium hydroxide (AR) was purchased from Tianjin Kemiou Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Ammonium hydrogen carbonate (AR) and kaolin (superfine) were purchased from Shanghai Myrell Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. The main components of kaolin are SiO2 (52.5%) and Al2O3 (45.0%). All materials were used directly without other treatment ( Table 1). 2.2 Catalysts preparation 2.2.1 Synthesis of CsNH4KPMoV CsNH4KPMoV catalysts was prepared on the basis of laboratory [3]. 28.8 g MoO3, 1.65 g V2O5 and 500 mL deionized water were added to a round bottom flask and stirred vigorously at 80 °C for 20 min. Then 85% H3PO4 (2.096 g) was added into the resulting suspension, stirred at 90 °C for 5 h and dried overnight at 80 °C to obtain solid powder. 15 g solid powder was dissolved in 300 mL deionized water and stirred 20 min at 80 °C. Then 0.99 g NH4HCO3 was dissolved in 50 mL of water, slowly added to the suspension and stirred for 10 min. Next, 1.41 g CsOH·H2O and 0.28 g KOH were added to the above suspension by the same way as NH4HCO3. After that, the suspension was stirred vigorously at 80 °C for 3 h and obtained yellow suspension. Then the insoluble matter in the suspension was filtered off and dried overnight at 80 °C. A yellow solid was obtained, which was composed of Cs(NH4)1.5K0.6H0.9PMo11VO40 and abbreviated as CsNH4KPMoV. 2.2.2 Synthesis of CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin CsNH4KPMoV supported on kaolin was prepared by impregnation method with water as the impregnation solvent. The specific operation was as follows: A certain amount of CsNH4KPMoV was dissolved in deionized water and dropped into a flask containing kaolin and stirred vigorously at 80 °C. The wet solid after impregnation was dried overnight at 80 °C, and then calcined in air at 350 °C for 12 h. The loading of the supported catalyst was adjusted by the amount of CsNH4KPMoV added. The obtained sample was recorded as xCsNH4KPMoV/kaolin, where x represents the load of CsNH4KPMoV. Basing on the above process, the synthesis mechanism of the catalyst is shown in Scheme 2. Firstly, Keggin-type heteropoly anion [PMo11VO40]4- was modified by Cs+-NH4 +-K+ to form CsNH4KPMoV. Then the supported catalyst CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin was prepared by impregnation, drying and calcination of CsNH4KPMoV and kaolin. There are negative charge and weak acid sites on the surface of kaolin, which was beneficial to the system. In order to make it easy to understand, the local area of the supported catalyst was also magnified. 2.3 Characterization of catalysts 2.3.1 Experimental analysis of structure Surface group analysis of the catalysts was carried out by Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy on a Thermo-Nicolet 6700 FT-IR spectrometer by using KBr pellets. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were obtained with a Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 1.5418 Å) at 40 kV and 200 mA, from 5° to 70° with a scan rate of 8°/min. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area and pore volumes analysis was performed from the nitrogen adsorption isotherms at − 196 °C with a Micromeritics Model ASAP 2020 instrument. Thermogravimetry analysis (TGA) of the samples was obtained on a Shimadzu DTG-60AH thermal analyzer. About 10 mg samples were heated to 600 °C under air flow at a constant heating rate of 10 °C·min−1. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was performed on a Thermo Scientific ESCALAB250Xi. Catalyst acidity was determined using ammonia temperature-programed desorption (NH3-TPD) on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 Chemisorption Analyzer. About 50 mg samples were placed in a quartz tube and first treated at 120 °C for 60 min at 50 mL·min−1 of He flow, then cooled to 50 °C. After that, the mixture gas of NH3 and He (5% NH3, 15 mL·min−1) was adsorbed at 100 °C for 60 min. At last, desorption profiles were recorded by the thermal conductivity detector (TCD) signal in a He flow (25 mL·min−1) by raising the temperature to 600 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C·min−1. Temperature-programmed oxidation-mass spectrometry (TPO-MS) measurements were performed in an AutoChem II 2920 Chemisorption Analyzer. About 150 mg of the sample was heated from 25 °C to 750 °C at a rate of 10 °C·min−1, using a mixture of O2 and He (2% O2). 2.3.2 Molecular simulation All calculations were performed at the DFT level with DMol3 program [55–57] in the Materials Studio of Accelrys Inc. The periodic supercells 2 × 1 × 1 of kaolinite (0 0 1) surface with a vacuum thickness of 20 Å were generated for HPVA adsorption [56]. In order to accurately calculate the interaction between HPVA and kaolin, all atoms were in a relaxed state during the geometry optimization process. The exchange-correlation energy was calculated by the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [58] functional. The DFT-Semi-core pseudopts (DSPP) method was used to describe the interaction between the atomic cores and electrons for metal atoms, and other atoms were treated with an all electron [59]. Meanwhile, the valence electron function was expanded into a set of numerical atomic orbitals through a double-numerical basis with polarization functions (DNP) [60], and partial occupancies was obtained by a smearing value of 0.005 hartree. A 2 × 1 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack grid was used for the adsorption configuration. The convergence criteria for structure optimization with tolerance energy of 2 × 10−5 eV/atom, maximum force of 0.05 eV/Å and maximum displacement of 2 × 10−3 Å, respectively. 2.3.3 Catalytic reaction experiment As shown in Fig. 1, selective oxidation of MAL to MAA was evaluated in a fixed-bed reactor at atmospheric pressure. Before evaluation, 4 g catalysts were tableted and sieved to obtain a particle size of 20–40 mesh. The catalysts were placed in the middle of the fixed bed reactor. The upper and lower ends of the catalyst were filled with appropriate amount of quartz wool, and then supported by wire mesh. O2 and N2 (carrier gas) with a volume ratio of 1/7.5 were injected into the reactor with the rate of 10 mL·min−1 and 75 mL·min−1, respectively. After temperature was increased to appropriate reaction temperature, the reactants (MAL/O2/N2/H2O) with the volume ratio of 1/2.6/19.5/5.3 were mixed firstly in a pre-mixer and then injected into the reactor. After the reaction was steady, the products were analyzed by Agilent-6820 GC equipped with a thermal conductivity cell detector (TCD) and a HP-INNOWAX capillary column. The highly volatile byproducts such as CO and CO2 were analyzed using an online GC with an HP-PLOT capillary column. The MAL conversion was calculated by Eq. (1) and the selectivity to MAA was calculated by Eq. (2). (1) C ( % ) = n MAL , F − n MAL , P n MAL , F × 100 % (2) S ( % ) = n MAA , P n MAL , F − n MAL , P × 100 % Where C (%) is the MAL conversion, S (%) is the selectivity to MAA. nMAL,F is the moles of MAL fed into the reactor, nMAL,P is the moles of MAL detected in the liquid phase product, nMAA,P is the moles of MAA detected in the liquid phase product. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts The FT-IR spectra of kaolin, CsNH4KPMoV and xCsNH4KPMoV/kaolin were analyzed, and the structure of the catalysts was investigated. The results are presented in Fig. 2. CsNH4KPMoV and xCsNH4KPMoV/kaolin catalysts exhibit the typical band of Keggin unit at about 1062, 965, 870, and 785 cm−1, which were attributed to P-O of PO4 tetrahedron, MoOd, Mo-Ob-Mo, and Mo-Oc-Mo asymmetric stretching vibrations, respectively [23,43,61]. The small band at about 1413 cm−1 of CsNH4KPMoV and supported xCsNH4KPMoV/kaolin catalysts can be assigned to the N-H deformation vibration of the NH4 + cations [23]. The peak at 1093 cm−1 was attributed to the dissymmetry stretching and Si-O-Si for kaolin [12]. In addition, the band at 469 cm−1 was attributed to the vibration of Si-O-Al [62]. The peaks of kaolin at 1093 and 469 cm−1 were also observed in all supported catalysts, indicating that the CsNH4KPMoV was successfully loaded on the kaolin carrier. And as the load of CsNH4KPMoV increased, the intensity of these two peaks became weaker and weaker. For supported catalyst xCsNH4KPMoV/kaolin, there were both characteristic peaks of CsNH4KPMoV and kaolin. These results further prove that CsNH4KPMoV was successfully loaded on kaolin. Fig. 3 shows the XRD patterns of the catalysts before reaction. The diffraction peaks of CsNH4KPMoV matched well with that of the CsPAV cubic phase (PDF 46–0481) [22] from Fig. 3(A), revealing the phase purity of the compound after calcination was high. The crystalline of kaolin was close to amorphous [63]. For the supported catalysts xCsNH4KPMoV/kaolin, all samples had diffraction patterns corresponding to pure CsNH4KPMoV. Even if the CsNH4KPMoV loading was only 33 wt%, the diffraction peak was almost the same as that of CsNH4KPMoV. In addition, no new peaks appeared and no peaks disappeared for all supported catalysts compared with pure CsNH4KPMoV, which indicates that the active component (CsNH4KPMoV) was successfully supported on kaolin and combined well with the carriers. At the same time, there was no decomposition of active components when CsNH4KPMoV was loaded on kaolin, which was consistent with the results of FT-IR in Fig. 2. In order to observe the shift of the diffraction peaks, the region from 25° to 27° was magnified. The diffraction peaks of CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin catalysts shifted slightly to lower angle sides after CsNH4KPMoV was loaded on kaolin from Fig. 3(B). For all samples, the strongest characteristic diffraction peak was about 26.2°, corresponding to the (222) plane of Keggin-type heteropoly acid. For CsNH4KPMoV, the crystal plane assigned to (222) at 26.32°, while the peak position shifted to 26.23°, 26.23°, 26.16° for 33CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin, 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin, and 67CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin, respectively. The phenomenon that the diffraction peak shifted to lower angles indicates that the d-spacing of the lattice increases [10]. Thermal stability of unsupported CsNH4KPMoV and support 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin catalysts in air at 50–600 °C were characterized by TG/DTA. Fig. 4 depicts the TG/DTA curves of kaolin, CsNH4KPMoV and supported catalysts 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin. There were two stages of weight loss in CsNH4KPMoV and 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin. The weight loss before 250 °C was crystalline water for both CsNH4KPMoV and 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin [64]. The weight loss of 250–450 °C was the decomposition of the active phase [10] and leading to form lacunary Keggin-type HPAs [65]. The decomposition of active phase refers to the decomposition of ammonium ion with release of ammonia and the elimination of acidic protons under the form of constitutional water [10,23]. Moreover, when the temperature reached about 450 °C, V4+ species were easily oxidized to V5+ species by air [23]. Thus, the increase in weight at about 450 °C of CsNH4KPMoV and 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin can be attributed to the reoxidation of V4+ to more stable V5+ under air [10]. The decrease in the weight of kaolin was mainly due to the water evaporation and dehydroxylation in the process of heating [63,66]. For catalyst CsNH4KPMoV, the decomposed of active phase began at 404 °C, while for 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin, the decomposition temperature of active phase increased to 420 °C. The active phase decomposition shifted to higher temperature for 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin catalysts, which was related to the improvement of thermal stability of the catalysts[64]. Good thermal stability is beneficial to the improvement of its catalytic performance. The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of kaolin, CsNH4KPMoV and xCsNH4KPMoV/kaolin catalysts were analyzed, and the results are shown in Fig. 5. The results reveal that the specific surface area of supported catalyst was higher than that of CsNH4KPMoV. All the curves exhibited type IV adsorption isotherms and had the H3 or H4 hysteresis loop. Although there was little difference in the isotherms of several samples, the hysteresis loop of kaolin was clearer than that of CsNH4KPMoV and kaolin has more obvious pore structure. Therefore, the average pore size of kaolin was smaller than that of CsNH4KPMoV ( Table 2). As shown in Table 2, the specific surface area, pore volume, and average pore size of the all samples are summarized. The specific surface area of kaolin was 15.3 m2·g−1, while that of pure CsNH4KPMoV was only 4.6 m2·g−1. The specific surface area of kaolin was 3.3 times of that of CsNH4KPMoV, thus kaolin can be used as a good carrier to support CsNH4KPMoV. When the CsNH4KPMoV loading was 67 wt%, 50 wt%, and 33 wt%, the specific surface area was 7.3 m2·g−1, 9.9 m2·g−1, 11.7 m2·g−1, respectively. With the increase of CsNH4KPMoV load, the specific surface area decreased. The increase of specific surface area promoted the exposure of acid sites and redox sites, which should be one of the reasons for the improvement of catalyst performance. Compared with kaolin, the pore volume of CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin decreased slightly, which was due to the fact that some CsNH4KPMoV were filled into the pores of kaolin. The NH3-TPD profiles of kaolin, CsNH4KPMoV, 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin and 33CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin are shown in Fig. 6. There was a broad desorption peak in the temperature range of 100–300 °C with the Tmax value being 197 °C for kaolin, corresponding to the weak acid sites [33]. NH3-TPD data indicate that the kaolin support was weakly acidic and can be used as an effective carrier to support HPAs. There were mainly two broad desorption peaks at 100–300 °C and 320–530 °C of CsNH4KPMoV. The Tmax value at 205 °C corresponded to weak acid sites and the Tmax value at 452 °C was strong acid sites. Weak acid sites appeared at 194 °C and strong acid sites appeared at 454 °C for 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin catalysts [10]. For catalysts 33CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin, three desorption peaks appeared at Tmax value 155 °C, 318 °C and 419 °C, corresponding to weak acid sites, mediate strong acid sites and strong acid sites, respectively [10,33,67]. The desorption peaks of 33CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin were very similar to that of CsNH4KPMoV, except that desorption peak temperature and strength was slightly lower. Because the xCsNH4KPMoV/kaolin catalyst will decompose and release NH3 when heating up, blank experiments without NH3 adsorption was carried out and the amount of ammonium ion was subtracted from that of desorbed ammonia on NH3-TPD profile. The acidity of 33CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin was 0.039 mmol·g−1, and the acidity was 0.11 mmol·g−1 for CsNH4KPMoV. The low acidity of 33CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin was related to the low content of the active ingredients (CsNH4KPMoV) and the lack of acidic sites. The desorption peaks of 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin supported catalysts and CsNH4KPMoV catalysts were almost the same. For 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin, the load of CsNH4KPMoV was 50 wt%, but acidity was 0.077 mmol·g−1, which was more than half of the acidity of CsNH4KPMoV, indicating that CsNH4KPMoV was well dispersed on the kaolin support and exposed most of the acidic sites. These results further suggests that the supported catalysts basically maintained the Keggin structure without decomposition of CsNH4KPMoV, and there were strong interaction between CsNH4KPMoV and kaolin [12]. The XRD results of Fig. 3 also reveal that the crystal phase of the supported catalyst was almost unchanged compared with that of CsNH4KPMoV. The retention of Keggin structure prove that the active component (CsNH4KPMoV) of the supported catalyst did not decompose, which was one of the reasons for the improvement of stability. 3.2 DFT simulation and the interfacial interactions In order to investigate the interfacial interaction between HPVA and kaolin, the structural stability of HPVA/kaolin catalyst was investigated by DFT simulation and the stable adsorption configuration obtained is shown in Fig. 7. According to the different adsorption sites of HPVA on kaolin, the adsorption configuration can be divided into the following three types. For adsorption configuration Fig. 7(A), the adsorption of O atom connected to Mo (O(Mo)). The adsorption of O atom connected to Mo and V in HPVA, and the adsorption of H atom connected to O atom (O(Mo/V)&H(O)) for Fig. 7(B). And for adsorption configuration Fig. 7(C), an O atom connected to Mo and an O atom connected to V in HPVA were adsorbed on kaolin (O(Mo/V)). In addition, the adsorption energies of the three adsorptions configuration were also calculated according to the Equ.3, and the results are listed in Table 3. (3) E ads= E HPVA/kaolin – E HPVA – E kaolin Among them, EHPVA/kaolin is the total energy of HPVA adsorbed on kaolin, and EHPVA and E kaolin are the energy of HPVA and kaolin, respectively. It can be concluded from Table 3 that the adsorption energies of the three adsorption configurations were all negative. The minimum adsorption distances (O and H atoms) were all around 1.0 Å, indicating that there was a strong attraction between HPVA and kaolin. For the adsorption configuration Fig. 7(A), Fig. 7(B) and Fig. 7(C), the adsorption energies were − 6.15 eV, − 5.13 eV, and − 5.17 eV, respectively. The absolute value of adsorption energy of Fig. 7(A) adsorption configuration was the largest, indicating that Fig. 7(A) configuration was the most stable. All the adsorption configuration of HPVA and kaolin (HPVA/kaolin) was multi-site adsorption from Fig. 7, and the large adsorption energy indicates that chemical adsorption has occurred between HPVA and kaolin. The partial density of states (PDOS) of kaolin adsorbed HPVA configuration (HPVA/kaolin) was calculated and the electronic interaction between HPVA and kaolin was further verified. As shown in Fig. 8, the s and p orbitals of the O atom in HPVA and the s orbital of the H atom in kaolin overlapped to a large extent in the range of − 18.6∼− 17.2 eV and − 7∼− 4.8 eV, revealing that there was a strong electronic interaction between HPVA and kaolin. The composition and the valence states of the elements in the near surface of CsNH4KPMoV and 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin were analyzed by XPS technique, and the results are shown in Fig. 9. The V 2p3/2 spectral zones are shown in Fig. 9(A) and Fig. 9(B). The binding energy of 518 eV and 517 eV belongs to V5+ and V4+ [10]. Vanadium species in the Keggin anion play an important role in the oxidation reaction of MAL through the transition of V4+ and V5+. The peaks of Mo 3d for catalysts CsNH4KPMoV and 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin are shown in Fig. 9(C) and Fig. 9(D). The binding energy of around 233.2 eV was assigned to Mo 3d5/2. Only Mo6+ peaks were presented because both CsNH4KPMoV and 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin were calcined in air. The change of Mo 3d5/2 spectra before and after loading was little, indicating that the presence of kaolin did not greatly affect the chemical state of Mo. The binding energy values and quantification results of Mo and V elements are obtained in Table 4. The ratio of V4+ for 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin (45%) was higher than CsNH4KPMoV (34%), indicating that more V5+ species was reduced to V4+ after CsNH4KPMoV loading on kaolin. This reduction occurred automatically and was related to the O2- ligands (lattice oxygen) in the Keggin structure [64,68]. When CsNH4KPMoV was loaded on kaolin, the lattice oxygen in heteropoly acid interacted strongly with kaolin from Fig. 7 (B) and Fig. 7 (C). The negative charge on the surface of kaolin [50] was transferred to the lattice oxygen in heteropoly acid and form electron-rich lattice oxygen, which was beneficial to the reduction of V5+ species. This was the reason for the increase of V4+ species after loading. V4+(VO2+) species are active species for the oxidation of MAL to MAA [22]. Kaolin support promoted the formation of V4+ species and the low chemical states of the V species were beneficial for improving the catalytic performance. Therefore, the incorporation of V in HPAs catalysts was very important for the oxidation of MAL. Changes in vanadium species indicate electronic interactions between the kaolin support and the active components (CsNH4KPMoV). The results of the partial density of states in Fig. 8 also proved that there was a strong electronic interaction between CsNH4KPMoVand kaolin. The N 1 s spectra of the CsNH4KPMoV and 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin are shown in Fig. 10. The peaks of the two samples were basically similar, and the loading process had no obvious effect on NH4 + in the active components. For the CsNH4KPMoV, the deconvoluted spectra for N 1 s exhibited two main peaks at 398.6 eV and 401.6 eV, corresponding to Mo6+ and NH4 +, respectively [23]. This conclusion also applied to 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin. By quantitative calculation, the ratio of Mo6+/NH4 + was 91.2/8.8 for sample CsNH4KPMoV and 90.9/9.1 for 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin. The nature of N in the catalyst has hardly changed before and after supporting. Therefore, the NH4 + cation in the active component played a role in regulating the acidity and alkalinity, but did not interact with the support. 3.3 Catalytic performance of the catalysts In order to study the catalytic performance of supported catalyst CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin for the oxidation of MAL to MAA, this work was based on the previous studies on the catalytic oxidation of MAL by unsupported heteropoly acid [3], and further discussion was carried out. The effects of loading and temperature on the reaction were mainly discussed, and the long-term performance of the catalyst was evaluated. At the same time, the catalytic performance was compared with that of unsupported pure CsNH4KPMoV. 3.3.1 Influence of the amount of CsNH4KPMoV active components The catalytic performance of a series of supported catalysts xCsNH4KPMoVkaolin is shown in Fig. 11. The performance of the supported catalyst was related to the CsNH4KPMoV loading. For pure CsNH4KPMoV, MAL conversion was 71.1% and selectivity to MAA was 88.9%. When the load of CsNH4KPMoV increased from 20 wt% to 50 wt%, MAL conversion increased from 52.8% to 81.8%. When the load continued to increase to 67 wt%, MAL conversion decreased. When the CsNH4KPMoV loading was 20 wt%, there were few active components and acid sites in the composite catalyst, so the catalytic performance was poor. However, when the CsNH4KPMoV loading was more than 67 wt%, the specific surface area of the catalyst decreased (Table 2), and the dispersion of the catalyst plays a leading role, resulting in the decrease of catalyst activity and the decrease of MAL conversion. The results are consistent with Jing’s study on the oxidation of isobutane to MAA [10]. When the CsNH4KPMoV loading was 50 wt%, the highest conversion was 81.8%, which was 10.7% higher than pure CsNH4KPMoV. 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin exposed more active sites and improved the oxidation performance of the catalyst. Besides, V4+ species was the active phase of MAL selective oxidation [23]. XPS results show that there were more V4+ species in 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin than in CsNH4KPMoV. Therefore, the activity of the supported catalyst increased. With the increase of CsNH4KPMoV load, the selectivity to MAA increased continuously. When the load of CsNH4KPMoV was 20 wt% and 33 wt%, the selectivity to MAA was 68.9% and 80.4%, respectively. For 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin and 67CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin, the selectivity to MAA was about 88% and changed little compared with CsNH4KPMoV. NH3-TPD results show that desorption peak temperature and intensity of 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin and CsNH4KPMoV were almost the same, so they had similar acidic sites and similar MAA selective. The catalytic performance was related to the loading amount of CsNH4KPMoV. This is mainly because the load affects the specific surface area and the exposure of active sites. The 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin catalyst was further discussed. 3.3.2 Influence of the temperature Fig. 12 shows the effect of temperature on catalytic performance of 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin. The conversion of MAL increased with the increase of temperature. MAL conversion was only 41.4% at 290 °C and reached to 84.5% at 345 °C, which was related to the activation of more MAL molecules in the reaction at high temperature. With the increase of temperature, the selectivity to MAA first increased from 65.1% to 88.2%, and then decreased to 73.4%. Proper increase of temperature can improve the catalytic performance (MAL conversion and selectivity to MAA) of the catalyst, but when the temperature exceeded a certain value, the by-product increased and the MAA selectivity decreased. The by-products were mainly acetic acid, CO and CO2. When the reaction temperature was 290–345 °C, the selectivity to acetic acid was in the range of 6.1–20.3%, the selectivity to COx was in the range of 5.7–14.6%. It is worth noting that 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin had the best catalytic performance. The MAL conversion was 81.8% and the selectivity to MAA was 88.2% when the temperature was 315 °C. 3.3.3 Performance comparison of 50 wt% supported catalyst and physical mixture The catalytic performance of 50 wt% supported catalyst and physical mixture was compared. From Table 5, for 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin supported catalysts, the MAL conversion and selectivity to MAA were 81.8% and 88.2% respectively at 315 °C. For the sample of physical mixture of kaolin and CsNH4KPMoV, under the same reaction conditions, the MAL conversion and selectivity to MAA were only 48.2% and 56.3%, less than 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin supported catalysts. Therefore, the performance of the physical mixture of kaolin and CsNH4KPMoV was much lower than that of the supported catalyst. 3.3.4 The catalytic stability of 50CsNH 4 KPMoV/kaolin In order to investigate the stability of the supported catalyst 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin, long-term life evaluation experiment was carried out at 315 °C for 100 h. During the reaction, the catalyst was not replaced. The catalytic performance of the catalyst is shown in Fig. 13. The MAL conversion and selectivity to MAA changed little with the increase of reaction time, and maintained at about 81% and 88%, respectively. In addition, the structure and performance of the catalyst did not change significantly after evaluation. These results confirm that the 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin supported catalyst had good stability and maintained high reaction efficiency for a long time. 3.4 General discussion In addition, the catalytic performance comparison of 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin and other supported catalysts in references for MAL oxidation is shown in Table 6. When SiO2 was used as carrier in MAL oxidation reaction, the catalytic performance was not good and generally needs to be further modified with ammonia, melamine, Cu, etc. Previous reports indicate that SiO2 carrier could react with heteropoly acid and lead to the decomposition of the active components to form MoO3. However, MoO3 was not conducive to the selective oxidation of MAL, so the catalytic performance decreased [28]. For 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin, the MAL conversion and selectivity to MAA were about 81% and 88% with the prolongation of reaction time. This is mainly attributed to the suitable acidity of kaolin, thus avoided the decomposition of active components and kept stable. The XRD characterization of the used supported catalyst (xCsNH4KPMoV/kaolin) was carried out to analyze the crystal phase change of the catalyst. Compared with the fresh xCsNH4KPMoV/kaolin catalysts (Fig. 3), the XRD crystallite of the used supported catalysts has almost no change, as shown in Fig. 14. This reveals that the supported catalyst was stable in the reaction process. The Keggin structure was maintained without decomposition and loss of active components. The catalyst life evaluation experiment in Fig. 13 also proved these results. From the NH3-TPD profile of Fig. 15, for the used catalyst 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin, there was a broad peak with the Tmax of 201 °C in the range of 150–300 °C, corresponding to weak acid sites. There was a broad peak between 320 °C and 530 °C with the Tmax value being 453 °C. Compared with the fresh 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin catalyst (Fig. 6), the NH3-TPD peak position and intensity of the used catalyst 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin almost did not change. This shows that the acid property of the used catalyst was basically the same as that of the fresh catalyst. The acidity of the used catalyst (50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin) was also analyzed, and the total acidity was 0.078 mmol·g−1, which was nearly the same as that of the fresh catalyst of 0.077 mmol·g−1. The acid strength and acidity of the catalyst did not decrease after use, indicating that the stability of the support catalyst was good. Fig. 16 is the XPS spectra of V 2p and N 1 s of the used 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin catalyst. The molar ratio of V5+/V4+ was 46/54, which was significantly lower than that of fresh catalyst (55/45). This was due to the partial reduction of V5+ to V4+ in the reaction process and shows that the vanadium species were reactive active species and participated in the reaction [37,64]. The deconvoluted spectra for N 1 s exhibited two main peaks at 398.6 eV and 401.6 eV, corresponding to Mo6+ and NH4 + [23], which was consistent with the fresh 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin catalyst. By quantitative calculation, the ratio of Mo6+/NH4 + was 92.6/8.4 for the used 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin. Compared with the fresh catalyst in Fig. 10, the proportion of NH4 + decreased slightly after 100 h reaction. There was a small amount of NH4 + decomposition during the reaction. The carbon deposition of the used 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin catalyst was studied by temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO) and monitored by online mass spectrometry (MS). The results are shown in Fig. 17. The TPO-MS pattern for m/e= 17 had a broad peak between 310 °C and 530 °C, which corresponds to the decomposition of ammonium in the catalyst to form NH3. For m/e= 18 from 310 °C to 530 °C can be associated with H2O [69–71]. The TPO-MS signals for m/e= 28 (CO2 and/or CO) and 44 (CO2) [72] can hardly be observed. The results show that there was almost no carbon deposition in the used 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin catalyst. Therefore, after 100 h of reaction, the catalyst still maintained good performance. 4 Conclusion A series of xCsNH4KPMoV/kaolin catalysts with different CsNH4KPMoV content were prepared for the oxidation of MAL. CsNH4KPMoV was successfully supported on kaolin, and the specific surface area of supported catalyst 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin was 2.1 times of that of CsNH4KPMoV. Kaolin carrier was weakly acidic and all the supported catalysts have strong acidic sites. CsNH4KPMoV was well dispersed on the kaolin support and maintained Keggin structure without decomposition of active components. Furthermore, the negative surface charge on the kaolin support promoted the reduction V5+ species in the CsNH4KPMoV to V4+ (VO2+) active species, which was beneficial to the improvement of their catalytic performance. In addition, the DFT calculation results suggest that there was a strong interaction between CsNH4KPMoV and kaolin, and chemical adsorption occurred. The loading of CsNH4KPMoV had an important effect on the catalytic performance of CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin catalysts. When the CsNH4KPMoV load was lower than 33 wt%, the strong acidic sites were less and the activity was poor. When the loading of CsNH4KPMoV exceeded 67 wt%, MAL conversion decreased due to the poor dispersion of catalyst. 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin had the best catalytic performance, and the MAL conversion and the selectivity to MAA were 81.8% and 88.2%, respectively. More importantly, the 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin catalyst exhibited good catalytic stability. There was no carbon deposition in the reaction process. The XRD patterns of the used catalyst were basically the same as that of the fresh catalyst, the acid strength and acidity of the used catalyst did not decrease, indicating that the catalyst had high stability. coredata.dc:description: The application of heteropoly acid catalyst in methacrolein (MAL) oxidation reaction is limited for its poor thermal stability and few active centers. Here, the supported catalyst of P-Mo-V heteropoly acid (CsNH4KPMoV) active components supported on kaolin were prepared, and were characterized by FT-IR, TG/DTA, XRD, N2-adsorption and desorption, NH3-TPD, TPO-MS and XPS. The results show that kaolin was weak acidity and the negative charge on the surface of kaolin promoted the reduction of V5+ species to V4+(VO2+) active species. There was a strong electron interaction between kaolin and HPVA, and chemical adsorption occurred by DFT calculations. Under optimal conditions, higher MAL conversion (81.8%) and Methacrylic acid (MAA) selectivity (88.2%) were obtained by 50CsNH4KPMoV/kaolin catalyst. The Keggin structure was maintained and the acid strength and acidity did not decrease after the catalyst was used continuously for 100 h. There was no carbon deposition in the reaction process.
coredata.dc:title: Kaolin supported heteropoly acid catalysts for methacrolein oxidation: Insights into the carrier acidity effect on active components
